title: Colour
text: simplevis, users adhere following rules adjusting colour: can customise colours via pal argument colouring variable, use *_col() *_col_facet() function, define col_var col_var numeric, continuous, bin quantile colouring methods available bin quantile, can modify colour breaks using col_breaks_n col_cuts arguments. simplevis, one colour concept, generally includes aspects features relevant visualisation family type. consistent method across functions, intended simplify colouring.

what: Customise colours via the pal argument
title: Colour
text: Default palettes can changed providing character vector hex codes pal argument.   Users can get access large amount colour palettes pals package.
code: gg_point(penguins,           x_var = bill_length_mm,           y_var = body_mass_g,           pal = "#da3490") gg_point_col(penguins,               x_var = bill_length_mm,               y_var = body_mass_g,               col_var = species,               pal = c("#da3490", "#9089fa", "#47e26f")) gg_point_col(penguins,               x_var = bill_length_mm,               y_var = body_mass_g,               col_var = species,               pal = pals::brewer.dark2(3))

what: If colouring by a variable, use a *_col() or *_col_facet() function, and define the col_var
title: Colour
text: colour variable, use *_col() function define variable coloured using col_var argument.
code: gg_point_col(penguins,               x_var = bill_length_mm,               y_var = body_mass_g,               col_var = species) gg_point_col_facet(penguins,                     x_var = bill_length_mm,                     y_var = body_mass_g,                     col_var = sex,                     facet_var = species,                    col_na_rm = TRUE)

what: If colouring by a numeric variable, continuous, bin and quantile methods are available
title: Colour
text: simplevis *_col() *_col_facet() functions support colouring categorical variable. addition, point, bar, hbar, tile, sf stars *_col() *_col_facet() functions support colouring numeric variable. specifying whether want defining whether col_method continuous (default), bin quantile.
code: plot_data <- ggplot2::diamonds %>%    slice_sample(prop = 0.01)  gg_point_col(plot_data,               x_var = carat,               y_var = price,               col_var = z) plot_data <- ggplot2::diamonds %>%    slice_sample(prop = 0.01)  gg_point_col(plot_data,               x_var = carat,               y_var = price,               col_var = z,              col_method = "bin") plot_data <- ggplot2::diamonds %>%    slice_sample(prop = 0.01)  gg_point_col(plot_data,               x_var = carat,               y_var = price,               col_var = z,              col_method = "quantile",              pal = pals::brewer.reds(4))

what: For bin and quantile, modify colour breaks using the col_breaks_n or col_cuts arguments
title: Colour
text: bin, col_breaks_n argument uses pretty algorithm aim roughly specified number pretty breaks. quantile, selects number bins equal percentiles. Alternatively, can specify exact breaks like specifying vector col_cuts argument. bin, vector values start either -Inf 0 finish Inf. quantile, vector probabilities 0 1.
code: gg_point_col(penguins,               x_var = bill_length_mm,               y_var = body_mass_g,               col_var = flipper_length_mm,               col_method = "bin",              col_breaks_n = 10) plot_data <- ggplot2::diamonds %>%    slice_sample(prop = 0.01)  gg_point_col(plot_data,               x_var = carat,               y_var = price,               col_var = z,              col_method = "bin",              col_cuts = c(0, 3, 4, Inf)) gg_point_col(penguins,               x_var = bill_length_mm,               y_var = body_mass_g,               col_var = flipper_length_mm,               col_method = "quantile",              col_breaks_n = 8) plot_data <- ggplot2::diamonds %>%    slice_sample(prop = 0.01)  gg_point_col(plot_data,               x_var = carat,               y_var = price,               col_var = z,              col_method = "quantile",              col_cuts = c(0, 0.5, 0.75, 0.9, 1))

title: Ggplotly
text: plotly library provides ggplotly function works convert ggplot objects interactive html widgets. simplevis package provides: text_var argument within gg_* wrapper functions use tooltip mutate_text function create tooltip easily based subset variables data plotly_camera function turn widgets camera plotly_col_legend function manipulate order plotly legends.

what: Turning a ggplot into an html widget
title: Ggplotly
text: plotly::ggplotly function provides ability convert ggplot interactive object.
code: plot <- gg_point_col(penguins,                       x_var = bill_length_mm,                       y_var = body_mass_g,                       col_var = species)  plotly::ggplotly(plot)

what: Turning off widgets other than the camera
title: Ggplotly
text: plotly_camera function turns widgets camera make cleaner graph.
code: plot <- gg_point_col(penguins,                       x_var = bill_length_mm,                       y_var = body_mass_g,                       col_var = species)  plotly::ggplotly(plot) %>%    plotly_camera()

title: Ggplotly
text: bar/hbar, line, point, pointrange/hpointrange, smooth, tile sf functions, simplevis provides method customise toolips. variable can added text_var simplevis function. variable used ggplotly tooltip tooltip = text added ggplotly function. simplevis provides mutate_text function can produce variable string variable names values tooltip. Note function converts column names sentence case using snakecase::to_sentence_case function. mutate_text function uses variables dataset defalut, subset can used desired.
code: plot_data <- penguins %>%    mutate_text()  plot <- gg_point_col(plot_data,                       x_var = bill_length_mm,                       y_var = body_mass_g,                       col_var = species,                       text_var = text)  plotly::ggplotly(plot, tooltip = "text") %>%    plotly_camera() plot_data <- penguins %>%    mutate_text(c("species", "flipper_length_mm"))  plot <- gg_point_col(plot_data,                       x_var = bill_length_mm,                       y_var = body_mass_g,                       col_var = species,                       text_var = text)  plotly::ggplotly(plot, tooltip = "text") %>%    plotly_camera()

what: Controlling the plotly colour legend order
title: Ggplotly
text: Sometimes ggplotly legend displays elements different order want . can reverse specify specific order using plotly_col_legend. Note, affects legend elements.
code: plot_data <- dplyr::sample_frac(ggplot2::diamonds, 0.05)    plot <- gg_point_col(plot_data,                       x_var = carat,                       y_var = price,                       col_var = color)   plotly::ggplotly(plot) %>%     plotly_camera() %>%     plotly_col_legend(order = c(2:7, 1))

title: Ggplotly
text: sf ggplots can also converted interactive ggplotly objects using method.
code: plot_data <- example_point %>%    mutate_text()  plot <- gg_sf_col(plot_data,                    col_var = trend_category,                    text_var = text,                   borders = example_borders)  plotly::ggplotly(plot, tooltip = "text") %>%    plotly_camera() col_cuts <- as.vector(quantile(example_point$median, probs = c(0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1)))  plot_data <- example_point %>%    mutate(quartile = case_when(median < col_cuts[2] ~ "Q1",                                median < col_cuts[3] ~ "Q2",                               median < col_cuts[4] ~ "Q3",                               TRUE ~ "Q4")) %>%    mutate_text()  plot <- gg_sf_col_facet(plot_data,                          col_var = trend_category,                          facet_var = quartile,                          text_var = text,                         borders = example_borders)  plotly::ggplotly(plot, tooltip = "text") %>%    plotly_camera()

title: Leaflet
text: leaflet library provides beautiful html widget maps. allow use basemaps, therefore ability zoom features context provide. simplevis provides wrapper functions map sf stars objects. Arguments aligned ggplot terminology make things simple user. sf functions: Data must sf object Data must POINT/MULTIPOINT, LINESTRING/MULTILINESTRING, POLYGON/MULTIPOLYGON geometry type Data must coordinate reference system (CRS) defined x_var y_var variables required stars functions: Data must stars object Data must coordinate reference system (CRS) defined x_var y_var variables required facetting functionality provided leaflet.

title: Leaflet
code: leaf_sf_col(example_point,              col_var = trend_category) leaf_sf_col(example_polygon,               col_var = density) leaf_stars_col(example_stars,                 col_var = nitrate,                 col_method = "bin",                 col_breaks_n = 4,                 col_na_rm = TRUE) leaf_stars_col(example_stars,                 col_var = nitrate,                 col_method = "bin",                 col_cuts = c(0, 500, 1000, 2000, Inf),                 col_na_rm = TRUE) leaf_sf_col(example_polygon,              col_var = density,              col_method = "quantile",              col_breaks_n = 4) leaf_sf_col(example_polygon,              col_var = density,              col_method = "quantile",              col_cuts = c(0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 0.95, 1)) leaf_stars_col(example_stars,                 col_var = nitrate,                 col_method = "bin",                 col_breaks_n = 7,                 col_na_rm = TRUE)

title: Leaflet
text: clickable popup default leafpop::popupTable variables, popups can adjusted subset column using popup_vars_vctr argument. hover label default colour variable, can adjusted using label_var variable.
code: leaf_sf_col(example_point,              col_var = trend_category,              popup_vars_vctr = c("site_id", "median")) leaf_sf_col(example_point,              col_var = trend_category,              label_var = site_id)

title: Leaflet
code: leaf_sf(example_point,          basemap = "dark")

title: Leaflet
text: Legend labels flexible ggplot2 wrapper functions. can adjust using col_labels argument, providing manual vector breaks.
code: leaf_sf_col(example_point,              col_var = trend_category,              col_labels = c("Better", "Same", "Worse"))

title: Leaflet
text: leaflet object produced, can add additional layers leaflet - although may effect popups labels. Note objects provided leaflet functions must transformed CRS 4326.
code: leaf_sf_col(example_point,              col_var = trend_category) %>%    leaflet::addPolygons(data = sf::st_transform(example_borders, 4326),                        color = "#35B779",                         weight = 3,                         fillOpacity = 0,                         opacity = 1)

title: Leaflet
text: leaflet basemap stack available use shiny apps. defaults top layer “light”. can set bounds adding vector bbox bounds. can also specify basemap top layer.
code: leaf_basemap(bounds = c(166.70047,-34.45676, 178.52966,-47.06345)) bb <- rnaturalearth::ne_countries(scale = "small",                                    country = "Indonesia",                                    returnclass = "sf") %>%     sf::st_bbox()    leaf_basemap(bounds = bb, basemap = "satellite")

what: Layer id’s for use in shiny
title: Leaflet
text: can add layer_id variable leaf_sf* functions use shiny, enables return value value clicked . enables program shiny specific things feature clicked upon. example, server.R code downloaded shiny_demo() updated follows, modal dialog can created graph compares feature value distribution values. server.R, adjust leaf_sf* function adding layer_id variable turning default popup FALSE. server.R, add ObserveEvent code observe feature clicked , add code put something something modal dialog box. Note input$leaf_marker_click$id returns value variable assigned layer_id. click event returns input$leaf_marker_click example map_id defaults “leaf” relates circlemarker. Refer information.
code: leaf_sf_col(     leaf_data(),     col_var = trend_category,     size_point = size_reactive,     col_title = title,      layer_id_var = site_id,     popup = FALSE   ) observeEvent(input$leaf_marker_click, {          site_median <- leaf_data() %>%        filter(site_id == input$leaf_marker_click$id) %>%        pull(median)          showModal(       modalDialog(         renderPlot(           gg_histogram(example_point, median,                         title = paste0(input$leaf_marker_click$id, " compared to all sites"),                         theme = gg_theme(font = "Helvetica", size_title = 16,  size_body = 15, gridlines_h = TRUE)) +             ggplot2::geom_vline(ggplot2::aes(xintercept = site_median), col = "red")         ),         easyClose = TRUE       )     )   })

title: Scales
text: simplevis uses consistent prefixes arguments help users enable users narrow looking enable Rstudio auto-complete provide options. general: Arguments relate x scale start x_ Agruments relate y scale start y_ Arguments relate colour scale start col_ Arguments relate facetting start facet_ Therefore, know want adjust x scale can’t think , can start typing x_ within simplevis function, press tab, presented lot options. can use arrow keys scroll , tab select. One deviation logic colour palette selected using pal argument consistently functions regardless whether colour palette relates colour scale just everything.

title: Scales
text: Defaults titles : title, subtitle caption x, y colour titles converted sentence case using snakecase::to_sentence_case function. can customise titles title, subtitle, x_title, y_title caption arguments.  can also request x_title using x_title = "" likewise y_title col_title.
code: gg_point_col(penguins,               x_var = bill_length_mm,               y_var = body_mass_g,               col_var = species,               title = "Adult penguin mass by bill length and species",              subtitle = "Palmer station, Antarctica",              x_title = "Bill length (mm)",               y_title = "Body mass (g)",              col_title = "Species")

title: Scales
text: can adjust labels provinding function named vector *_labelsargument. categorical variables converted sentence case default using snakecase::to_sentence_case. Numeric variables generally converted using scales::label_comma() default, sometimes converted scales::label_number(). can turn simplevis default transformations labels using function(x) x.
code: gg_point_col_facet(penguins,                    x_var = bill_length_mm,                    y_var = body_mass_g,                    col_var = sex,                    facet_var = species) col_labels <- c("F", "M") names(col_labels) <- sort(unique(penguins$sex)) col_labels #> female   male  #>    "F"    "M"  gg_point_col_facet(penguins,                    x_var = bill_length_mm,                    y_var = body_mass_g,                    col_var = sex,                    facet_var = species,                     y_title = "Body mass (kg)",                    x_labels =  scales::label_comma(),                    y_labels = function(x) glue::glue("{x / 1000} kg"),                     col_labels = col_labels,                    facet_labels = ~ stringr::str_to_upper(stringr::str_sub(.x, 1, 1)))

title: Scales
text: simplevis graphs numeric scales default : starting zero numeric scales bar graphs. starting zero numeric scales graphs. can use x_zero y_zero arguments change defaults.  Adjust number breaks numeric x /y scales.  Balance numeric scale equivalence positive negative values.  Zero lines default numeric scale includes positive negative values, can turned desired using *_zero_line argument. Transform numeric x y scales adding ggplot2 scale_*_continuous layer.
code: gg_point_col(penguins,               x_var = bill_length_mm,               y_var = body_mass_g,               col_var = species,               x_zero = TRUE,               y_zero = TRUE) gg_point_col(penguins,               x_var = bill_length_mm,               y_var = body_mass_g,               col_var = species,               x_breaks_n = 6,               y_breaks_n = 10) gg_point_col(penguins,               x_var = bill_length_mm,               y_var = body_mass_g,               col_var = species,               y_balance = TRUE) gg_point_col(penguins,              x_var = bill_length_mm,              y_var = body_mass_g,              col_var = species) +   ggplot2::scale_y_log10(     name = "Bill length mm",     breaks = function(x) pretty(x, 4),     limits = function(x) c(min(pretty(x, 4)), max(pretty(x, 4))),     expand = c(0, 0)   )

title: Scales
text: simplevis automatically orders hbar graphs character variables alphabetically.  inherent order character variable want plot , convert variable factor, give appropriate levels.  Discrete scales can reversed easily using relevant y_rev x_rev argument.  Simple hbar vbar plots made gg_bar() gg_hbar can ordered size using y_reorder x_reorder. functions, need reorder variables data wish ordered.  functions, need reorder relevant variables want. tidytext package provides method reordering within facets.
code: plot_data <- ggplot2::diamonds %>%   mutate(cut = as.character(cut)) %>%    group_by(cut) %>%   summarise(price = mean(price))     gg_hbar(plot_data,          x_var = price,          y_var = cut) cut_levels <-  c("Ideal", "Premium", "Very Good", "Good", "Fair")  plot_data <- ggplot2::diamonds %>%   mutate(cut = as.character(cut)) %>%    mutate(cut = factor(cut, levels = cut_levels)) %>%    group_by(cut) %>%   summarise(price = mean(price))   gg_hbar(plot_data,          x_var = price,          y_var = cut) plot_data <- ggplot2::diamonds %>%   mutate(cut = as.character(cut)) %>%    group_by(cut) %>%   summarise(price = mean(price))   gg_hbar(plot_data,          x_var = price,          y_var = cut,         y_rev = TRUE) plot_data <- ggplot2::diamonds %>%   mutate(cut = as.character(cut)) %>%    group_by(cut) %>%   summarise(price = mean(price))     gg_hbar(plot_data,          x_var = price,          y_var = cut,          y_reorder = TRUE) plot_data <- penguins %>%   group_by(species, sex) %>%   summarise(body_mass_g = mean(body_mass_g, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%   ungroup() %>%   mutate(species2 = forcats::fct_rev(tidytext::reorder_within(species, body_mass_g, sex)))  gg_hbar_col_facet(   plot_data,   x_var = body_mass_g,   y_var = species2,   col_var = species,   facet_var = sex,   facet_na_rm = TRUE,   facet_scales = "free_y",   y_labels = function(x) stringr::str_to_sentence(stringr::word(x, sep = "___")),   col_legend_none = TRUE)

title: Scales
text: Customise colour title. Note colour labels converted sentence case default simplevis, can turn want occur using function(x) x.  Reverse palette.  Reverse order coloured bars.
code: plot_data <- ggplot2::diamonds %>%   group_by(cut, clarity) %>%   summarise(average_price = mean(price))  gg_hbar_col(plot_data,              x_var = average_price,              y_var = cut,              col_var = clarity,             col_labels = function(x) x,              pal_rev = TRUE) plot_data <- ggplot2::diamonds %>%   group_by(cut, clarity) %>%   summarise(average_price = mean(price))  gg_hbar_col(plot_data,              x_var = average_price,              y_var = cut,              col_var = clarity,             col_labels = function(x) x,              pal_rev = TRUE) plot_data <- ggplot2::diamonds %>%   group_by(cut, clarity) %>%   summarise(average_price = mean(price))  gg_hbar_col(plot_data,              x_var = average_price,              y_var = cut,              col_var = clarity,             col_labels = function(x) x,              col_rev = TRUE)

title: Scales
text: can quickly remove NA values setting x_na_rm, y_na_rm, col_na_rm facet_na_rm arguments TRUE.
code: gg_point_col_facet(penguins,                     x_var = bill_length_mm,                     y_var = body_mass_g,                     col_var = sex,                     facet_var = species,                     col_na_rm = TRUE)

title: Scales
text: expand scale use x_expand y_expand arguments ggplot2::expansion function, allows expand either directions x y additive multiplative way.
code: plot_data <- storms %>%   group_by(year) %>%   summarise(wind = mean(wind))  gg_line(plot_data,          x_var = year,          y_var = wind,          x_expand = ggplot2::expansion(add = c(0, 5)),         y_expand = ggplot2::expansion(mult = c(0, 0.025)))

title: Scales
text: general plots positioned exactly data provided. Exceptions bar*() hbar*(), positions bars side--side default (.e. dodged).  However, option stack bars also available.  point allows jitter x y direction.  pointrange hpointrange allow specify amount dodge , desired.
code: plot_data <- penguins %>%    group_by(species, sex) %>%    summarise(body_mass_g = mean(body_mass_g, na.rm = TRUE))    gg_bar_col(plot_data,             x_var = species,             y_var = body_mass_g,             col_var = sex) plot_data <- penguins %>%    group_by(species, sex) %>%    summarise(body_mass_g = mean(body_mass_g, na.rm = TRUE))    gg_bar_col(plot_data,             x_var = species,             y_var = body_mass_g,             col_var = sex,            stack = TRUE,            col_na_rm = TRUE,             size_width = 0.5) gg_point(penguins,                 x_var = species,                 y_var = body_mass_g,                 x_jitter = 0.2,                 alpha_point = 0.5) plot_data <- penguins %>%   group_by(sex, species) %>%   summarise(middle = median(body_mass_g, na.rm = TRUE),             lower = quantile(body_mass_g, probs = 0.25, na.rm = TRUE),             upper = quantile(body_mass_g, probs = 0.75, na.rm = TRUE))  gg_pointrange_col(   plot_data,   x_var = species,   y_var = middle,   ymin_var = lower,   ymax_var = upper,   col_var = sex,   col_na_rm = TRUE,   y_title = "Body mass g",   x_dodge = 0.3)

title: Scales
code: plot_data <- penguins %>%    group_by(species) %>%    summarise(body_mass_g = mean(body_mass_g, na.rm = TRUE))    gg_bar_col(plot_data,         x_var = species,         y_var = body_mass_g,         col_var = species,         col_legend_none = TRUE,        size_width = 0.5)

title: Shiny
text: difficulty shiny making shiny apps display graphs work mobile phones portrait mode. often look unreadable (portrait), : titles neeed start far left plot, left-aligned titles need wrapped x scale needs minimum labels look clutterred legends need bottom font sizes need appropriate simplevis provides mobile support plots mobile argument, makes changes.  simplevis templates, mobileDetect function ui.R associated javascript www/js/mobile.js returns TRUE FALSE input$isMobile value user mobile device. input$isMobile TRUE FALSE value can added mobile argument simplevis gg_* function server.R. One reliable way ensure plot viewed mobile users ui.R use conditional panels provide plotly object non-mobile users plot object mobile users. method demonstrated simplevis templates.
code: plot_data <- storms %>%   group_by(year, status) %>%   summarise(wind = mean(wind))  gg_point_col(penguins,               x_var = bill_length_mm,               y_var = body_mass_g,               col_var = species,               title = "Adult penguin mass by bill length and species",              mobile = TRUE)

title: Simplevis
text: simplevis package ggplot2 leaflet wrapper functions aims make visualisation easier less brainpower required.

title: Simplevis
text: simplevis supports many visualisation family types.

what: 4 functions per family: colouring, facetting, neither or both
title: Simplevis
text: visualisation family generally four functions. based whether visualisation : coloured variable facetted (*()) coloured variable, facetted (*_col()) facetted, coloured variable (*_facet()) coloured variable facetted (*_col_facet()) simplevis, ggplot2 concepts col fill aesthetics unified one simplicity. premise 4 types visualisation common visualisation family, therefore useful make functions quickly enable . arguments variables required unquoted, follow *_var format (.e. x_var, y_var, col_var facet_var) example, code shows combinations code output gg_point*() family.
code: gg_point(penguins,           x_var = bill_length_mm,           y_var = body_mass_g) gg_point_col(penguins,               x_var = bill_length_mm,               y_var = body_mass_g,               col_var = sex) gg_point_facet(penguins,                 x_var = bill_length_mm,                 y_var = body_mass_g,                 facet_var = species) gg_point_col_facet(penguins,                     x_var = bill_length_mm,                     y_var = body_mass_g,                     col_var = sex,                     facet_var = species)

title: Simplevis
text: simplevis works pipe. order variables functions always x_var, y_var, col_var facet_var appliable. , familiar package, may choose name arguments x_var, y_var, col_var facet_var. variables always named. can enable great looking plots minimal code effort.
code: penguins %>%    gg_point_col_facet(bill_length_mm, body_mass_g, sex, species)

title: Simplevis
text: functions, change colour palette supplying vector hex code colours pal argument.  method colouring variable, just colouring geometry visualisation single colour.  Refer colour article information.
code: gg_point(penguins,           x_var = bill_length_mm,            y_var = body_mass_g,            pal = "#da3490") gg_point_col(penguins,               x_var = bill_length_mm,               y_var = body_mass_g,               col_var = species,               pal = c("#da3490", "#9089fa", "#47e26f"))

title: Simplevis
text: lots arguments available modify defaults. general, arguments consistent prefixes based x_*, y_*, col_* facet_*. helps identify explore need using Rstudio autocomplete. common arguments : *_title adjust titles x, y col scale *_labels adjust labels x, y, col facet scale *_na_rm remove NA observations x, y, col facet scale *_zero start zero numeric x y scales *_breaks_n number numeric bins breaks numeric x, y col scales aim *_rev reverse order categorical x, y, col facet scales *_expand add padding x y scale *_balance balance numeric scale around zero, zero centre col_legend_none turn legend . illustrates customise titles control labels possible ways.  Refer scales article information. size_ alpha_ prefixes used modify size opacity various aspects visualisation.
code: plot_data <- storms %>%   group_by(year, status) %>%   summarise(wind = mean(wind))  col_labels <- c("Hcane", "TDep", "TSt") names(col_labels) <- sort(unique(plot_data$status)) col_labels #>           hurricane tropical depression      tropical storm  #>             "Hcane"              "TDep"               "TSt"  gg_line_col_facet(plot_data,                    x_var = year,                    y_var = wind,                    col_var = status,                    facet_var = status,                    title = "US storms storm wind speed, 1975-2020",                   x_title = "Storm year",                   y_title = "Average storm wind speed",                   col_title = "Storm status",                   x_labels = function(x) stringr::str_sub(x, 3, 4),                   y_labels = scales::label_comma(accuracy = 0.1),                   col_labels = col_labels,                   facet_labels = ~ stringr::str_to_sentence(stringr::str_wrap(.x, 5)),                   y_zero = TRUE,                   y_breaks_n = 6,                   y_expand = ggplot2::expansion(add = c(0, 10)),                   size_point = 1)

title: Simplevis
text: can adjust theme simplevis plot providing ggplot2 theme object theme argument. can also create quick themes simplevis gg_theme() function.  Refer themes article information.
code: custom_theme <- gg_theme(   pal_body = "white",   pal_title = "white",   pal_subtitle = "white",   pal_background = c("#232323", "black"),   pal_gridlines = "black",    gridlines_h = TRUE,   gridlines_v = TRUE)  gg_point_col(penguins,              species,              x_var = bill_length_mm,              y_var = body_mass_g,               theme = custom_theme)

title: Simplevis
text: simplevis also supports sf stars maps. sf refers point, line polygon features, whereas stars refers arrays (.e. grids). gg_sf*() functions, data must sf object POINT/MULTIPOINT, LINESTRING/MULTILINESTRING, POLYGON/MULTIPOLYGON geometry type. gg_stars*() functions, data must stars object. gg_sf*() gg_stars*() functions: Data must coordinate reference system (CRS) defined x_var y_var variables required Borders can added maps providing sf object borders argument. following example objects provided withing package learning purposes: example_point, example_polygon example_stars. borders argument allows user provide sf object context map (e.g. coastline administrative boundaries).   simplevis also provides leaflet wrapper functions sf stars objects. functions work similar way, leaf_ prefix. Note borders argument available leaf_*() functions. Refer leaflet article information.
code: gg_sf_col(example_point,            col_var = trend_category,            borders = example_borders) gg_stars_col(example_stars,              col_var = nitrate,              col_na_rm = TRUE,              borders = example_borders) leaf_sf_col(example_point,              col_var = trend_category)

title: Simplevis
text: gg_* leaf_* wrapper functions produce ggplot leaflet objects. means layers can added functions way ggplot2 leaflet object. Note need add aesthetics additional geom_* layers. example adds error bars, labels, new y scale. Note 25 percentiles 75 percentiles used demonstrate errorbars, rather confidence intervals normally used error bars.  patchwork package can used patch visualisations together.  ggplot objects can converted interactive html objects using plotly::ggplotly function plotly library. simplevis also offers customisability making tooltips (.e. hover values) ggplotly. Refer ggplotly article information.
code: plot_data <- penguins %>%   filter(!is.na(body_mass_g)) %>%    group_by(species) %>%   summarise_boxplot_stats(body_mass_g)   gg_bar_col(plot_data,            x_var = species,            y_var = middle,            col_var = species,            col_legend_none = TRUE,            y_title = "Body mass g") +   ggplot2::geom_errorbar(ggplot2::aes(x = species, ymin = lower, ymax = upper),                          width = 0.2) +   ggplot2::geom_text(ggplot2::aes(x = species, y = lower - 500, label = middle),                      col = "white") +   ggplot2::scale_y_continuous(     name = "Body mass g",     breaks = function(x) pretty(x, 5),     limits = function(x) c(min(pretty(x, 5)), max(pretty(x, 5))),     expand = c(0, 0)   ) library(patchwork)  p1 <- gg_point(penguins,                 x_var = species,                 y_var = body_mass_g,                 x_jitter = 0.2,                 alpha_point = 0.5)   p2 <- gg_boxplot(penguins,                   x_var = species,                   y_var = body_mass_g)   p1 + p2 plot <- gg_point_col(penguins,                      x_var = bill_length_mm,                      y_var = body_mass_g,                      col_var = species)  plotly::ggplotly(plot) %>%   plotly_camera()

title: Simplevis
text: Variable types supported different families functions outlined . : Categorical refers character, factor, logical classes. Numeric refers double integer classes. * refers numeric, date datetime variable, values must bins mutually exclusive equidistant.

title: Bar ggplot. — gg_bar
text: data data frame structure plotted untransformed. Required input. x_var Unquoted variable x scale (.e. character, factor, logical, numeric, date datetime). numeric, date datetime, variable values bins mutually exclusive equidistant. Required input. y_var Unquoted numeric variable y scale. Required input. text_var Unquoted variable used customised tooltip combination plotly::ggplotly(plot, tooltip = "text"). Defaults NULL. pal Character vector hex codes. alpha_fill opacity fill. Defaults 1. alpha_line opacity outline. Defaults 1. size_line size outlines bars. size_width Width bars. Defaults 0.75. title Title string. title_wrap Number characters wrap title . Defaults 75. subtitle Subtitle string. subtitle_wrap Number characters wrap subtitle . Defaults 100. x_balance numeric x variable, add balance x scale zero centre. Defaults FALSE. x_expand vector range expansion constants used add padding x scale, per ggplot2 expand argument ggplot2 scales functions. x_labels function named vector modify x scale labels. NULL, categorical variable labels converted sentence case. Use function(x) x keep labels untransformed. x_na_rm TRUE FALSE whether include x_var NA values. Defaults FALSE. x_breaks_n numeric date x variable, desired number intervals x scale, calculated pretty algorithm. Defaults 5. x_reorder categorical x variable, TRUE FALSE whether x variable variable reordered x variable. Defaults FALSE. x_rev categorical variable, TRUE FALSE whether x variable variable reversed. Defaults FALSE. x_title X scale title string. Defaults NULL, converts sentence case spaces. Use "" like title. x_title_wrap Number characters wrap x title . Defaults 50. x_zero numeric x variable, TRUE FALSE whether minimum x scale zero. Defaults FALSE. x_zero_line numeric x variable, TRUE FALSE whether add zero reference line x scale. Defaults TRUE positive negative values x_var. Otherwise defaults FALSE. y_balance numeric y variable, add balance y scale zero centre y scale. y_breaks_n numeric date y variable, desired number intervals y scale, calculated pretty algorithm. Defaults 5. y_expand vector range expansion constants used add padding y scale, per ggplot2 expand argument ggplot2 scales functions. y_labels function named vector modify y scale labels. Use function(x) x keep labels untransformed. y_na_rm TRUE FALSE whether include y_var NA values. Defaults FALSE. y_title y scale title string. Defaults NULL, converts sentence case spaces. Use "" like title. y_title_wrap Number characters wrap y title . Defaults 50. y_zero numeric y variable, TRUE FALSE whether minimum y scale zero. Defaults TRUE. y_zero_line numeric y variable, TRUE FALSE whether add zero reference line y scale. Defaults TRUE positive negative values y_var. Otherwise defaults FALSE. caption Caption title string. caption_wrap Number characters wrap caption . Defaults 80. theme ggplot2 theme. mobile Whether plot displayed mobile device. Defaults FALSE.

title: Boxplot ggplot. — gg_boxplot
text: data data frame generally structure transformed boxplot statistics (alternatively structure summary boxplot statistics). Required input. x_var Unquoted categorical variable x scale (.e. character, factor, logical). Required input. y_var Unquoted numeric variable y scale stat = "boxplot" selected. pal Character vector hex codes. alpha_fill opacity fill. Defaults 0.5. alpha_line opacity outline. Defaults 1. alpha_point opacity outlier points. Defaults 1. size_line size outlines boxplots. Defaults 0.5. size_point size outlier points. Defaults 1.5. size_width Width boxes. Defaults 0.5. title Title string. title_wrap Number characters wrap title . Defaults 75. subtitle Subtitle string. subtitle_wrap Number characters wrap subtitle . Defaults 75. x_expand vector range expansion constants used add padding x scale, per ggplot2 expand argument ggplot2 scales functions. x_labels function named vector modify x scale labels. NULL, categorical variable labels converted sentence case. Use ggplot2::waiver() keep x labels untransformed. x_na_rm TRUE FALSE whether include x_var NA values. Defaults FALSE. x_rev categorical x variable, TRUE FALSE whether x variable variable reversed. Defaults FALSE. x_title x scale title string. Defaults NULL, converts sentence case spaces. Use "" like title. x_title_wrap Number characters wrap x title . Defaults 50. y_balance numeric y variable, add balance y scale zero centre y scale. y_breaks_n numeric date x variable, desired number intervals x scale, calculated pretty algorithm. Defaults 5. y_expand vector range expansion constants used add padding y scale, per ggplot2 expand argument ggplot2 scales functions. y_labels function named vector modify y scale labels. Use ggplot2::waiver() keep y labels untransformed. y_title y scale title string. Defaults NULL, converts sentence case spaces. Use "" like title. y_title_wrap Number characters wrap y title . Defaults 50. y_zero numeric y variable, TRUE FALSE whether minimum y scale zero. Defaults TRUE. y_zero_line numeric y variable, TRUE FALSE whether add zero reference line y scale. Defaults TRUE positive negative values y_var. Otherwise defaults FALSE. caption Caption title string. caption_wrap Number characters wrap caption . Defaults 80. stat String "boxplot" "identity". Defaults "boxplot". ymin_var Unquoted numeric variable minimum whisker y scale stat = "identity" selected. ylower_var Unquoted numeric variable minimum box y scale stat = "identity" selected. ymiddle_var Unquoted numeric variable middle box y scale stat = "identity" selected. yupper_var Unquoted numeric variable maximum box y scale stat = "identity" selected. ymax_var Unquoted numeric variable maximum whisker y scale stat = "identity" selected. theme ggplot2 theme. mobile Whether plot displayed mobile device. Defaults FALSE.

title: Boxplot ggplot. — gg_boxplot
Boxplot ggplot. — gg_boxplot
code: library(dplyr) library(simplevis) library(palmerpenguins)  gg_boxplot(penguins,             x_var = species,             y_var = body_mass_g) #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing non-finite values (stat_boxplot).   plot_data <- penguins %>%   group_by(species) %>%   summarise_boxplot_stats(body_mass_g)  outliers <- penguins %>%    group_by(species) %>%    summarise_boxplot_outliers(body_mass_g)  gg_boxplot(plot_data,             x_var = species,             ymin_var = min,             ylower_var = lower,             ymiddle_var = middle,             yupper_var = upper,             ymax_var = max,             stat = "identity",             y_title = "Body mass g",             y_breaks_n = 4) +   ggplot2::geom_point(ggplot2::aes(x = species, y = body_mass_g),              size = 0.75, col = pal_viridis_reorder(1),              data = outliers)

title: Boxplot ggplot that is coloured. — gg_boxplot_col
Boxplot ggplot that is coloured. — gg_boxplot_col
code: library(simplevis) library(dplyr) library(palmerpenguins)  gg_boxplot_col(penguins,                 x_var = species,                 y_var = body_mass_g,                 col_var = sex,                 col_na_rm = TRUE)   #For ggplotly, pipe in plotly::layout(boxmode = "group") layer  plot_data <- penguins %>%   group_by(species, sex) %>%   summarise_boxplot_stats(body_mass_g)  outliers <- penguins %>%    group_by(species, sex) %>%    summarise_boxplot_outliers(body_mass_g)  size_width <- 0.5  gg_boxplot_col(plot_data,                x_var = species,                ymin_var = min,                ylower_var = lower,                ymiddle_var = middle,                yupper_var = upper,                ymax_var = max,                col_var = sex,                size_width = size_width,                stat = "identity",                y_title = "Body mass g",                y_breaks_n = 4,                 col_na_rm = TRUE) +                ggplot2::geom_point(ggplot2::aes(x = species, y = body_mass_g, col = sex),                       size = 0.75,                       position = ggplot2::position_dodge(width = size_width),                      data = outliers)

code: library(dplyr) library(simplevis) library(palmerpenguins)  plot_data <- penguins %>%   group_by(sex, species) %>%   summarise(middle = median(body_mass_g, na.rm = TRUE),             lower = quantile(body_mass_g, probs = 0.25, na.rm = TRUE),             upper = quantile(body_mass_g, probs = 0.75, na.rm = TRUE)) #> `summarise()` has grouped output by 'sex'. code: library(dplyr) library(simplevis) library(palmerpenguins)  plot_data <- penguins %>%   mutate(year = as.character(year)) %>%   group_by(year, sex, species) %>%   summarise(middle = median(body_mass_g, na.rm = TRUE),             lower = quantile(body_mass_g, probs = 0.25, na.rm = TRUE),             upper = quantile(body_mass_g, probs = 0.75, na.rm = TRUE)) #> `summarise()` has grouped output by 'year', 'sex'. You can override using the #> `.groups` argument.  gg_hpointrange_col_facet(   plot_data,   y_var = year,   x_var = middle,   xmin_var = lower,   xmax_var = upper,   col_var = sex,   facet_var = species,   col_na_rm = TRUE,   x_title = "Body mass g",   y_labels = function(x) stringr::str_sub(x, 3, 4),    y_dodge = 0.2)

code: library(dplyr) library(simplevis) library(palmerpenguins)  plot_data <- penguins %>%   group_by(sex, species) %>%   summarise(middle = median(body_mass_g, na.rm = TRUE),             lower = quantile(body_mass_g, probs = 0.25, na.rm = TRUE),             upper = quantile(body_mass_g, probs = 0.75, na.rm = TRUE)) #> `summarise()` has grouped output by 'sex'. title: Summarise boxplot stats. — summarise_boxplot_stats
Summarise boxplot stats. — summarise_boxplot_stats
code: library(simplevis) library(dplyr) library(palmerpenguins)  penguins %>%    group_by(species) %>%    summarise_boxplot_stats(body_mass_g)  #> # A tibble: 3 x 6 #>   species     min lower middle upper   max #>   <fct>     <dbl> <dbl>  <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 Adelie     2850  3350   3700  4000  4775 #> 2 Chinstrap  2900  3475   3700  3950  4550 #> 3 Gentoo     3950  4700   5000  5500  6300  penguins %>%    group_by(sex, species) %>%    summarise_boxplot_stats(body_mass_g, names_vctr = LETTERS[1:5])  #> # A tibble: 8 x 7 #>   sex    species       A     B     C     D     E #>   <fct>  <fct>     <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> <dbl> #> 1 female Adelie     2850  3175 3400   3550  3900 #> 2 female Chinstrap  2900  3350 3550   3700  4150 #> 3 female Gentoo     3950  4450 4700   4875  5200 #> 4 male   Adelie     3325  3800 4000   4300  4775 #> 5 male   Chinstrap  3250  3725 3950   4100  4550 #> 6 male   Gentoo     4750  5300 5500   5700  6300 #> 7 NA     Adelie     2975  3300 3475   3700  4250 #> 8 NA     Gentoo     4100  4375 4688.  4800  4875

text: data tibble dataframe. Required input. x_var Unquoted numeric variable x scale. Required input. model_bw bw argument stats::density function. Defaults "gaussian". model_n n argument stats::density function. Defaults 512. model_trim trim argument stats::density function. Defaults FALSE.

title: Calculate horizontal numeric breaks. — sv_numeric_breaks_h
text: var_vctr numeric vector horizontal scale determine breaks . balance Add balance y axis zero centre horizontal scale. breaks_n desired number intervals horizontal axis, calculated pretty algorithm. title: Calculate vertical breaks. — sv_numeric_breaks_v
text: var_vctr numeric vector vertical scale determine breaks . balance Add balance vertical axis zero centre vertical scale. breaks_n desired number intervals vertical axis, calculated pretty algorithm. Defaults 5. zero TRUE FALSE whether minimum vertical scale zero. Defaults TRUE. trans string specifying transformation vertical axis scale, "log10" "sqrt". Defaults "identity". mobile Whether plot displayed mobile device. Defaults NULL.

title: Automatically adjust x_zero and x_zero_line if necessary — sv_x_zero_adjust
text: x_var_vctr vector values x scale. x_balance Add balance x axis zero centre x scale. applicable facet_scales equals "fixed" "free_y". x_zero TRUE FALSE whether minimum x scale zero. Otherwise FALSE. description Generate list x_zero x_zero_line elements adjusted necessary.
